14.text: My name is Sonia Massai. I teach Shakespeare studies at King's College London.

20.text: Shakespeare's language has a very musical quality to it and this quality often survives in translation,

27.text: because translators become fascinated with the sound, the material quality of that language.

33.text: Shakespeare for me was an amazing, life-changing discovery.

36.text:

39.text:

44.text:

49.text: But listening to the long flowing lines of blank verse, you can

53.text:
feel the rhythm and the pace and the
sheer material quality of those words.

60.text:
A few lines that are so memorable that
audiences literally wait for them to enjoy:

66.text: [From Twelfth Night] 'Make me a willow cabin at your gate, / And call upon my soul within the house. /

73.text: Write loyal cantons of contemned love / And sing them loud even in the dead of night. /

80.text: Halloo thy name to the reverberate hills / And make the bubbling gossip

84.text: of the air / Cry out, "Olivia"'. [Ends]. To appreciate the fact that these lines are all about

90.text: sound, songs, words... this is Shakespeare's daring you to believe in the power of

97.text: language to move Olivia and to move us.
